author: bridge-bot
content: <thegaram33> anyone knows what's going on with blobs? blobscans hows 5k gwei base fee

author: bridge-bot
content: <justindrake> 5k gwei/blob is correct :) Price discovery, seemingly led by Arbitrum consuming many more blobs recently.

author: bridge-bot
content: <justindrake> Arbitrum in black at the bottom

author: bridge-bot
content: <hkalodner> Btw Arbitrum automatically switched over to posting with calldata once that became cheaper

author: bridge-bot
content: <SamWilsn> Base seems to be increasing as well. Is there a non-stacked version of the graph?

author: bridge-bot
content: <justindrake> Oh you're right, base too in blue (clear when you remove Arbitrum)

author: bridge-bot
content: <thegaram33> looks like Arbitrum is the only rollup that has this feature implemented (re @hkalodner: Btw Arbitrum automatically switched over to posting with calldata once that became cheaper)

author: bridge-bot
content: <SamWilsn> Is that a feature we want?

author: bridge-bot
content: <vb271828> in the long run, calldata will be negligible compared to blob data

author: bridge-bot
content: <vb271828> once we have DAS

author: bridge-bot
content: <SamWilsn> If I understand blobs correctly (and I'm sure I don't), isn't it Pretty Bad for blobs to be more expensive than calldata because blobs can get thrown away while calldata cannot?

author: bridge-bot
content: <thegaram33> I think so, since blob throughput is still fairly limited. this was discussed briefly at one of the rollcall breakout rooms. but with zk it's non-trivial to maintain two DA encodings. (re @SamWilsn: Is that a feature we want?)

author: bridge-bot
content: <vb271828> actually if pectra gets both 7623 and blob count increase, then calldata becomes 2.5x more expensive and blobs become 3x more plentiful, so it starts not making sense at all

author: bridge-bot
content: <vb271828> so yeah, I don't expect hybrid calldata/blob architectures to make any sense in the long or even medium term

author: bridge-bot
content: <vb271828> but it's of course good that arbitrum has this now so we can get some offload

author: bridge-bot
content: <adietrichs> yes, for now it's great for everyone if a few L2s retain the ability to switch to calldata. but agree, this will become irrelevant as we move further along our DA scaling roadmap (starting with Pectra)

author: bridge-bot
content: <vb271828> blob price is at 125 gwei now, a 200 byte tx (assuming no/awful compression) would cost 25k gwei ~= 90m nanodollars = $0.09

author: bridge-bot
content: <vb271828> ok wow we're still impressively not-too-expensive

author: bridge-bot
content: <vb271828> But it does mean we're back to having an incentive to actually care about putting compression in ðŸ™‚

author: bridge-bot
content: <zkLumi> We also have the ability to switch but kept it manual for now. In this case we didnâ€™t need to. (re @adietrichs: yes, for now it's great for everyone if a few L2s retain the ability to switch to calldata. but agree, this will become irrelevant as we move further along our DA scaling roadmap (starting with Pectra))

author: bridge-bot
content: <justindrake> 5k gwei/blob is correct :) Price discovery, seemingly led by Arbitrum consuming many more blobs recently.

author: bridge-bot
content: <mcutler95> Hi all. We're actively investigating the impressive spike in the Blob Base Fee that started at around block 20134107. Here Blob Base Fee is ~2 Gwei. By block 20134110 it hit ~3 Gwei and then began to run up. So far, my spot analysis suggests that the Blob Base Fee peaked at 7471 Gwei at block 20134272 (https://etherscan.io/block/20134272#blobinfo). This cause L2 Type 3 batches to 'go negative' at around block 20134175 (when the Blob Base Fee hit 323 Gwei). Here we can see that a Taiko Type 3 transaction 'overpaid' vs Calldata by about 10%. https://www.ethernow.xyz/tx/0x48b8001f2b26222f85b9b3d19e4f6bb2549d2e83622ec9be40b5711c01a12a15?txTab=blobs

author: bridge-bot
content: <mcutler95> As the Blob Base Fee climbed, pretty much all Type 3 transactions were 'underwater'... many rather substantially. For instance, here's a Blast Batch that 'overpaid' by >4.5 ETH (!!). https://www.ethernow.xyz/tx/0x13684351276dc01bc75347ab78db451ab35f06d3ff9e67e078a2f25ed15c6010?txTab=blobs

author: bridge-bot
content: <mcutler95> Anyone else digging on in this situation? If so, please DM me!

author: bridge-bot
content: <mcutler95> Hi all. We're actively investigating the impressive spike in the Blob Base Fee that started at around block 20134107. Here Blob Base Fee is ~2 Gwei. By block 20134110 it hit ~3 Gwei and then began to run up. So far, my spot analysis suggests that the Blob Base Fee peaked at 7471 Gwei at block 20134272 (https://etherscan.io/block/20134272#blobinfo). This caused L2 Type 3 batches to 'go negative' at around block 20134175 (when the Blob Base Fee hit 323 Gwei). Here we can see that a Taiko Type 3 transaction 'overpaid' vs Calldata by about 10%. https://www.ethernow.xyz/tx/0x48b8001f2b26222f85b9b3d19e4f6bb2549d2e83622ec9be40b5711c01a12a15?txTab=blobs

author: bridge-bot
content: <mcutler95> As the Blob Base Fee climbed, pretty much all Type 3 transactions were 'underwater'... many rather substantially. Many by 10x. A few by 50x. For instance, here's a Blast Batch that 'overpaid' by >4.5 ETH (!!). https://www.ethernow.xyz/tx/0x13684351276dc01bc75347ab78db451ab35f06d3ff9e67e078a2f25ed15c6010?txTab=blobs

author: bridge-bot
content:
<thegaram33> we've also noticed something weird about blob propagation. observed this after the spike, so blocks were not congested anymore, but we had a backlog of batches to commit to L1:

when we sent multiple blob-carrying transactions to a geth node (the default limit is 16 txs / account), it seems that many of these were not propagated to the network. we've observed multiple times that either Etherscan didn't even pick up these transactions, or they were pending for a long time, even though fees were above market. blobs were only included after we replaced the transactions a few minutes later.

I wonder if nodes implement certain heuristic to rate limit blobs from the same node or sender account? or maybe the p2p layer was congested? has anyone experienced this before?
